---
title: "Two Sum"
author: "Isaac Flath"
date: "2024-01-28"
categories: [array, hash table]
description: "Determine if an integer is a palindrome"
---

>Problem Source:  Leetcode

## Problem Description

Given an array of integers nums and an integer target, return indices of the two numbers such that they add up to target.

You may assume that each input would have exactly one solution, and you may not use the same element twice.

You can return the answer in any order.

### tests

::: {#0b7c0474 .cell execution_count=1}
``` {.python .cell-code}
def test(fn):
    target = 9
    nums = [2,7,11,15]
    expected = [0,1]
    actual = fn(nums, target)
    assert sorted(actual) == expected 

    target = 6
    nums = [3,2,4]
    expected = [1,2]
    actual = fn(nums, target)
    assert sorted(actual) == expected 

    target = 6
    nums = [3,3]
    expected = [0,1]
    actual = fn(nums, target)
    assert sorted(actual) == expected 
```
:::


## Solutions

### Brute Force 

The way to brute force this problem would be to try every possible combination of 2 indices until one solves the problem.  This would mean a loop in a loop, or  complexity.

+ Time Complexity: `O(n^2)`
+ Space Complexity: `O(1)`

::: {#f48a6ff4 .cell execution_count=2}
``` {.python .cell-code}
from typing import List
def twoSum(nums: List[int], target: int) -> List[int]:
    for index1, num1 in enumerate(nums):
        desired_num = target - num1
        for index2, num2 in enumerate(nums):
            if (num2 == desired_num) and (index1 != index2):
                return [index1, index2]

test(twoSum)
```
:::


### Hash Map

Instead of trying every possible combination we can calculate the other number we need, and do a lookup to see if we have seen that number we need.  By doing this we only need 1 loop.

+ Time Complexity: `O(n)`
+ Space Complexity: `O(n)`

::: {#d8bd3b6c .cell execution_count=3}
``` {.python .cell-code}
from typing import List
def solution(nums: List[int], target: int) -> List[int]:
    hashmap = {}
    for i,num in enumerate(nums):
        need = target - num
        if need in hashmap:
            return [i,hashmap[need]]
        hashmap[num] = i

test(twoSum)
```
:::
